title: Dark arts, dirty laundry and an almighty M&A brawl
text:
One podcast to start: don't miss DD's Kaye Wiggins on the FT News Briefing podcast today, where she explains why private equity firms are targeting UK companies, and how the public is pushing back. Listen here, or wherever you get your podcasts.

The M&A powerhouses behind an epic corporate duel

One reason messy corporate quarrels usually end in settlements: no one wants to see their dirty laundry in open court.

Today two of the shiniest brands in the dealmaking world — an elite law firm and a top CEO adviser — can only rue why their client decided to take a case to the limit.

Last week the FT reported on the corporate communications group Teneo's attempt to help its client, Cigna, escape the $50bn-plus merger it signed up for with rival US health insurer Anthem back in 2015. 

Things got ugly, and what started as a behind-the-scenes brawl became a public spectacle in a Delaware court. (The judge even referred to Teneo as being skilled in “the darker arts of influencing the media and public discourse”.)

DD's Sujeet Indap took a deep-dive into the court documents chronicling the healthcare giants' 2019 legal drama. They paint a picture of one of the nastiest disputes in recent dealmaking history, and offer a glimpse into the hidden forces (ie, shrewd public relations advisers) behind the veil of mega mergers and acquisitions.

Here's how it all began: David Cordani, Cigna's chief executive, was under the impression that he would join Anthem upon the deal's closing, eventually replacing Anthem's then-CEO Joe Swedish. 

When it turned out that Cordani appeared to be the victim of a bait-and-switch by Anthem, in which he would be sidelined at the new company, Cigna called in back-up.

Cigna, according to evidence that the court relied on, resorted to a “covert communications campaign” that involved not just Teneo but Wachtell Lipton, the prestigious New York law firm.

The campaign involved secretive leaks to The Wall Street Journal, a search for unflattering photos and even silly code names to keep people in the dark — Wachtell Lipton was referred to internally by Cigna as “the tea company”.

Alas, their covert manoeuvring has come to light. And worse yet, the court has denied Cigna a $1.85bn termination fee from Anthem, which it thought it was entitled to over the busted deal.

Next time, the high-priced advice ought to be on helping clients to avoid the witness stand and discovery requests at all costs.

Go deep into the details with Sujeet's full story here.

Caffeine headache: is your coffee getting more expensive?

There's been a lot of chatter in the “virtual” FT breakroom over how we take our coffee. (With a splash of oat milk? Black, like the great Japanese artist Takashi Murakami? By drone?) Our colleagues in Singapore seem to have some of the best options.

But our daily fixes, no matter how they're prepared, could soon become a costlier vice, as a surge in coffee prices threatens to trickle into costs paid by consumers.

The futures benchmark in New York for arabica, the high-end coffee bean, hit a four-and-a-half year high of almost $1.70 a pound, up almost 70 per cent from the previous year.

Natural disaster, social unrest and logistical bottlenecks are among the culprits.

Top bean producer Brazil has suffered the worst drought in almost a century, leading to the first supply shortfall in the coffee market in four years, as anti-government protests in Colombia caused a delay in exports earlier this year, further pushing up prices.

Retailers are feeling the pressure. The German coffee chain Tchibo said it was raising prices by 50 cents to €1 a pound, while JM Smucker, the US parent of Folgers and Dunkin' coffee, also forecasted price increases. Nespresso, Nestlé's premium coffee unit, said that in the US it was taking a wait-and-see approach.

Hedge funds have woken up to the scent of pricier coffee, piling into the arabica futures market last month to accumulate a large net long position — aka a bet that prices will rise — equivalent to Colombia's annual production.

“Some of the drama we've seen in terms of the change of the price has to be attributed to these huge capital inflows we've seen coming in from non-physical players,” Max Copestake, an executive director at Marex, told the FT.

Unwilling to pay a premium on your morning brew? The FT's Anjli Raval has a delicious alternative.

The Greensill show returns with a surprise FT guest

In the sprawling set of government inquiries into the collapse of Greensill Capital, we've heard hours and hours of testimony. 

British lawmakers have grilled everyone from former prime minister David Cameron to Lex Greensill himself, in a bid to shed more light on the financial and political scandal.

One key character whose voice has been missing though is Sanjeev Gupta, the metals magnate whose business — and financing arrangements with Greensill — are now under investigation by the UK's Serious Fraud Office. Gupta, who has denied wrongdoing and pledged to co-operate with the investigation, withdrew from a parliamentary committee hearing on Tuesday.

But while DD was disappointed not to hear from the “Man of Steel” himself, the star speaker on Tuesday was someone who knows almost as much about Gupta's complicated tangle of corporate entities: the FT's very own Cynthia O'Murchu.

A stalwart of the FT's investigation desk, Cynthia broke down the dark arts of invoice financing at the heart of the Greensill and Gupta fiasco in characteristically forensic fashion. Click here to watch the replay.

Elsewhere, the Greensill news never stops. Here are some of the latest headlines since we last checked in: 

  • Greensill Capital's insurers claim they were misled by the finance group

  • Sanjeev Gupta in talks with Glencore over loan

  • Greensill used taxpayer loans to cut exposure to Sanjeev Gupta

  • UK government applied ‘unusual' pressure for Greensill over Covid loans

Job moves

  • The Gates Foundation has announced a contingency plan that would allow Melinda French Gates to resign as co-chair of the foundation and receive “personal resources” from her estranged husband Bill Gates in the wake of the pair's divorce proceedings. More here.

  • German lender Commerzbank will rehire its former Wirecard analyst Heike Pauls, who was fired in February after being particularly bullish on the fraudulent payments group up until its collapse. A Frankfurt court ruled on Tuesday that the bank didn't have sufficient grounds to fire Pauls.

  • NBC News executive vice-president of communications Mark Kornblau will join SoftBank as its new global head of communications in August. He will be based in New York.

  • Rio Tinto has named Isabelle Deschamps as its chief legal officer and head of external affairs, replacing Barbara Levi. She will join the Anglo-Australian miner in Melbourne this October from Dutch paint manufacturer AkzoNobel, where she is currently general counsel.

  • Latham & Watkins has named Ravi Purohit, former managing director at Blackstone Infrastructure Partners, as a partner in the corporate department in New York. He will be a member of the M&A and private equity practice and global vice-chair of the energy and infrastructure group.

Smart reads 

The Lion of Los Angeles Behind every big deal is a bigger personality. In the case of Amazon's MGM mega-deal, it was Aryeh Bourkoff — Hollywood's hottest banker and the force behind M&A advisory firm LionTree. Some say he's a more slick socialite than a skilled banker. Either way, the deal gets done. (Hollywood Reporter)

Media circus Ever wondered what it's like to be a fly on the wall at Sun Valley's “summer camp for billionaires”? Former FT media correspondent Kenneth Li, the FT's news editor Matthew Garrahan and others recount their juiciest stories — some of which never made it to press. (New York Times reporter Edmund Lee's Substack)

Space race Rocket launching moguls Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos aren't the only ones preparing for lift-off. Investors are keeping their eyes on the skies as new space exploration start-ups enter the fray. (NYT)
